paragraph_0@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: Welp, hello there. The Vanilla Minecraft help section has now been replaced with this guide because, well, you're probably more interested in what this addon does rather then how to play Minecraft at this point.

paragraph_1@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: To be fair though, replacing the vanilla help section isn't enough to contain all the information you really need to know before playing around with this addon, so you should check out the addon wiki here: https://prehistoric-rift.fandom.com/wiki/Prehistoric_Rift_Wiki

paragraph_0@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: The following humans have contributed assets to this addon in the past:

paragraph_1@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: Vivek (various tribute items, new exotic meats, new command staff)

paragraph_2@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: Professor Squiggles (Utahraptor Claw, Harvest Staff, various journal drawings)

paragraph_3@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: Koda Soda (apatosaurus platform, various journal drawings)

paragraph_6@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: The Gaming Baryonyx (Old Raw Dodo Meat textures, various journal drawings)

paragraph_7@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: DTRaptor (Old Command Staff, old exotic meats)

paragraph_9@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: All sounds used in this addon were taken from YouTube

paragraph_0@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: I'm just a human being based in the Philippines who makes Minecraft Bedrock addons for fun. Besides this addon, I also work on many other projects, like Project Cenozoic and Borgy's Mobs.
In case you have any problems with the addon, make sure to come here.

paragraph_1@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: In case something doesn't work (like certain features being missing), here's a quick rundown on what to do.

paragraph_2@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: First of all, make sure you are on a version which this addon supports. I usually try to get it to support the newest (non-beta) versions of Minecraft, so there's that.

paragraph_3@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: Next, make sure to turn on these toggles first before creating the world.

paragraph_4@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: Finally, make sure to activate cheats. Yes this may sound stupid, but many of the important things needed for most of the entities to work require it.

header_1@how_to_play_common.header.$text: In case you have other addons installed

paragraph_5@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: This addon is incompatible with other addons that modify player data. The only workaround for this is to put the behavior pack on the top of all other packs.

paragraph_6@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: It's either a feature or a bug. If it's a bug welp try come to my discord server for help. Link is in the "About Me" section.

paragraph_0@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: Although there is not much to be listed here, the following is still essential:

paragraph_1@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: Using this Staff allows you to trigger the special abilities of most of the ridable creatures. Right click/tap and hold once to activate an ability, and right click and hold/tap and hold for a long time, then release to change the ability to be used. Try it out while riding different creatures to see what happens!

paragraph_2@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: Using this Staff allows the creature you're riding to harvest certain items at a higher efficiency than by hand. Different creatures can harvest different items with varying efficiencies. Some creatures may even extract resources from certain blocks!

paragraph_3@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: It's technically not a staff, but using this item allows you to use machines that are attached to the saddle of the creature you are riding. For example, cannons!

paragraph_4@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: This tool can be used to make tamed creatures that are not sitting to attack the nearest wild mob until they die or are out of range. That thing in the center required to craft it is the Parasaurolophus Horn btw, which is rarely dropped by Parasaurolophuses. Skeletons and Strays may be also found using this.

paragraph_5@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: This tool is required to change the shape of certain furniture.

paragraph_0@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: This section covers food items that can be crafted

paragraph_1@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: Treats are generally food items that are needed to tame and breed creatures. Different creatures will prefer different treats.

paragraph_2@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: Berry treats are packed berries that are favored by most herbivores.

paragraph_3@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: Grass Treats are pieces of grass that have been compressed into a tasty snack for grazing herbivores. Besides wheat, you can also use grass or tall grass.

paragraph_4@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: Rooted Treats are a mix of root vegetables that serve as a starchy treat for most herbivores. Besides potatoes, you can also use carrots or beetroot.

paragraph_5@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: Leafy Treats are a mix of various types of leaves that serve as a tasty treat for herbivores. Especially leaf eating herbivores! You can use any kind of leaf block to craft these treats.

paragraph_6@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: Flesh treats are sweet strips of flesh that has been wrapped around a bone as a tasty treat for most carnivores. All meat (except chicken and fish meats) can be used to craft this treat.

paragraph_7@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: Fish treats are whole fish that have been punctured through the mouth with a bone. This serves as a tasty treat for fish eating creatures. Salmon can also be used to craft this treat.

paragraph_8@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: Carrion treats are strips of rotting flesh that has been wrapped around a bone as a tasty treat for certain carnivores.

paragraph_9@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: Bug treats are strips of raw hemolymph that has been wrapped around a bone as a tasty treat for certain carnivores.

paragraph_10@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: Mixed Meat is an amalgamation of meat items. Its the meat based counterpart of Golden Apples.

paragraph_11@how_to_play_common.paragrap.$text: Enchanted Mixed Meat is the meat based counterpart of Enchanted Golden Apples.

paragraph_1@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: This meat is dropped by practically every creature that in this addon. There's nothing much else to explain about it.

paragraph_2@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: A special meat dropped by Dodos. When eaten raw, you'll get hunger. But if consumed cooked, it will grant you absorption.

paragraph_3@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: A special meat dropped by Parasaurolophus. When eaten raw, you'll get hunger. But if consumed cooked, it will grant you resistance.

paragraph_4@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: Loot sacks are the inventories of unfortunate people who got eaten by the carnivorous creatures of the Rift. They are usually dropped by carnivores, and come in 4 rarities. Depending on the rarity of the loot sack, you can get some really good loot.

paragraph_5@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: Tribute items are dropped by their respective creatures. Each tribute item is unique to each creature. They are used to do taxidermy and to create journals.

paragraph_0@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: These are vanilla items that I have given their own crafting recipes because at this point they need to be obtained normally in some way or another.
Why the hell did I add furniture to a dinosaur addon? Well this is my addon, I can add whatever I want to it.

paragraph_1@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: First, you need to find furniture blueprints. In order to get these blueprints, you need to kill random wild carnivores for a chance to get loot sacks. Blueprints drop from loot sacks of uncommon rarity or higher.

paragraph_2@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: Next, you need to place the blueprint down to get a phantom of the furniture that you will make. Finally, interact with it while holding the material required to make the furniture. For example, in the case of phantoms of wooden furniture, use wooden planks, while in the case of phantoms of plastic furniture, use plastic frames.

paragraph_3@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: Now there might be times when you need to adjust furniture. While the furniture you want to edit is still in its phantom mode, interact with it while holding the furniture tool.

paragraph_0@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: So you want to tame a creature for yourself? Well then...

paragraph_1@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: How creatures are tamed varies based on the type of creature you're dealing with. The main feature in common to taming any of the creatures is that they require treats. Treats can be crafted, and are separated into tiers depending on their effectiveness.

paragraph_2@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: Creatures in this tier cannot be tamed because either they're too stupid or they're too dangerous. Includes Dodos, Coelacanths, and Megapiranhas.

paragraph_3@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: Creatures in this tier can be tamed as either adults or babies. Just walk right up to them and give them some treats. Includes Parasaurolophus, Stegosaurus, Triceratops, and Megaloceros.

paragraph_4@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: Creatures in this tier can be given treats as babies for them to be tamed. Adults on the other hand must be given treats across periods of time in order for them to be tamed. Includes Utahraptor, Dimetrodon, Sarcosuchus, Anomalocaris, Saurophaganax, Direwolf, and Baryonyx.

paragraph_5@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: Creatures in this tier cannot be tamed in the wild no matter what. They must be killed for a chance to obtain eggs for you to hatch, in order to raise the baby. Includes Tyrannosaurus and Apatosaurus.

paragraph_0@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: Assuming that you have managed to tame a creature, you should be able to take care of them. This section details how.

paragraph_1@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: If your tamed creature in injured, you should feed them any regular foods within Minecraft to feed them. Herbivores should be given plant related items like crops and leaf blocks, while carnivores should be given meat related items.

paragraph_2@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: If you ever decide to face a really tough enemy for whatever reason, you can feed your creature enchanted golden apples (herbivores only) or enchanted mixed meat (carnivores only). They will gain the effects a human eating an enchanted golden apple would.

paragraph_3@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: You can't harm your own tames. If you want to get rid of them entirely, you have to give them euthanasia, which is crafted (requires fermented spider eye, regular plastic frames, and an iron ingot) as shown below:

paragraph_4@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: In order to breed creatures, they need to be tamed to begin with. You should then feed them their favorite treat, and from there they will produce an egg. All details pertaining to egg hatching will be in the "Eggs" section.

paragraph_0@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: If you've taken a glance of the MCPEDL page you may have noticed that there are journals that give details on various creatures within the addon. Well guess what, you can also read them in game.

paragraph_1@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: You need to craft a journal enscriber, as shown below. All kinds of planks can be used.

paragraph_3@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: Once you place it down, you need to place a book on it by interacting with it while holding a book. Finally, interact with it while holding a tribute item to get the journal of the owner of that tribute item!

paragraph_0@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: Eggs are obtained by breeding creatures within this addon, or killing certain other creatures. In order for the egg(s) to hatch, you need to put them in an area of a certain temperature. Environmental modifiers like the biome the egg is in, whether or not it's raining, and altitude will affect the temperature of the egg.

paragraph_1@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: When the egg starts to hatch, it will emit green particles. It can take a really long time for eggs to hatch. You can speed up the hatching process by placing the eggs near a tamed Dimetrodon in an area at a certain temperature. Just make sure to give the Dimetrodon stimulants every now and then.

paragraph_2@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: If you want to move an egg, sneak and right click/tap on the egg to pick it up.

paragraph_0@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: Currently, the only mob that can have mounted weapons is the Apatosaurus, but whatever, I'm still adding this section especially in case other mobs that can have mounted weapons get added.

paragraph_1@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: Stationary weapons are powerful weapons, but their main drawback is that they require ammunition and they cannot be easily moved from one place to another without a mob that has a platform. As of now there are 3 kinds of stationary weapons available.

paragraph_2@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: Cannons are weapons that fire explosives at a far off distance. They require cannonballs to work.

paragraph_3@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: Mortars are weapons that drop shells on top of mobs at a far off distance. They require mortar shells to work.

paragraph_4@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: Catapults are weapons that hurl powerful boulders at mobs at a far off distance. If the target doesn't die somehow they will get paralyzed for 30 seconds. They require catapult boulders to work.

paragraph_5@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: The Apatosaurus Platform is an exclusive saddle for the Apatosaurus only. It comes with 3 seats and slots for a chest and one stationary weapon. Equipping it onto an Apatosaurus is as simple as opening its inventory and placing it in the saddle slot.

paragraph_6@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: In order to equip the weapon of your choice on the platform, right click/tap and hold on a platformed Apatosaurus with the weapon. Then, in order to place ammunition on the weapons, right click/tap and hold on the Apatosaurus with the required ammunition. Apatosauruses with cannons can have 24 cannonballs, while those with mortars can have 12 mortar shells.

paragraph_7@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: Finally, in order to fire the weapon, use the command console! The crafting recipe for that item can be found in the tools section.

paragraph_8@how_to_play_common.paragraph.$text: The wrench can be used to rotate stationary weapons and remove them from an Apatosaurus Platform.
